comments.commentBody:
Martin has disappeared and presumably is in Japan. I am starting to come out of my funk, now that KC has taken a 3-1 edge and Murphy's error led to the KC win tonight.

I'm with those who thought this puzzle lacked any excitement. It is fairly straight forward as a puzzle and the theme is as weak as any Sunday theme can be. An anagram of theme is ET MEH.

Managed to pick up all three wines this month (albeit with some vintage substitutions), enjoyed the last one tonight with dinner.

We started with the Cayron 2012, paired with a rich, generously cheese-topped French onion soup. We found this wine concentrated and very youthful, with a powerhouse nose of blackberry and raspberry fruit, baking spice, oak, and menthol. And on the palate it seemed to have a real tension, with a gamut of fruity, herbal, and woody flavors being tightly wound into a compact, elegant package. Hints of pepper and licorice were also detectable, though the finish was definitely more herbal, with a distinctly bitter quality. It also got funkier/gamier with time open,but on the second day, the wine declined precipitously. Fantastic the first night though.

The soup was not a terrible pairing, but not ideal. We gave it a chance. At the very least, the level of richness helped the soup to keep up, and the wine's fine-grained tannins and moderate acid provided contrast. However, it still felt like a bit of a clash, like switching between two different radio stations. The Gigondas frankly seemed to beg for something a bit more substantial.

But at any rate this seemed like a good choice for the first wine---it had a lot of really accessible qualities and made for easy, relaxed drinking. We loved that it seemed to be refined and rustic all at the same time; not unlike the desired aesthetic in so many other contexts these days, for whatever that is worth.

Mike R: I disagree with your flawed logic. It's 2015, 300 years ago was 1715 and there were no social programs available let alone, available to minorities or the poor.

Additionally, I previously read the study about equally qualified but racially different candidates applying for the same job. All candidates were asked the same questions and gave basically the same responses. To suggest that relationship to a felon because it poses a greater risk of who knows what to be a criteria for hiring is a classic example of racism. I would be willing to bet that if someone visited your family tree, there probably would be a felon or two on some of the branches. There's no family that is completely exempt from having a felon somewhere on the family tree.
We really enjoyed this and used turkey wings and the legs.

Amazing how consistent the TImes is.  I don't think it's a problem that Sanders doesn't kiss babies.  I guess the Times wants us to think so.   It must be so much easier to write an article like this one than to, say, analyze what the economic and budget impact of Sanders' policy proposals would be, or what his foreign policy positions' implications might be, compared to the other candidates.  A few anecdotes, and well-placed quotes add up to nicely written gossip here, nothing more.
Just like there is separation of Church and State, there should be a separation of Church and Newspaper.

As a retired Family Physician, I agree with DAK based on my experience with general and sub specialty surgeons over 40 yrs of medical practice. With rare exceptions,they tend to view the patient's problem thru their own narrow lens. They are indeed mechanics in their thinking. With due respect toward my surgical colleagues, I've more than once held my patients back from the operating table and the patients got better without the application of a scalpel.
I'm struck by the similarity with Clarence Thomas' story: climb out of poverty, attain success with the help of the collective others, then do all you can to deny that help to others.

But individual harm should be dealt with by individuals in a small, cost-effective way for everyone.

********

Well yeah, except that corporate mentality is such that it refuses to recognize individual harm. Why should the responsibility for being "cost effective" be on the individual? The most cost effective answer is for companies to own up to their wrong doing, whatever form it takes. But then that might affect profit.
Carson is running to be the presidential candidate of a political party has gradually become unmoored from reality the past 20 years. As such, he is perfectly emblematic of the moment.

No local merchants were stocking the 2011 Les Pallieres, but we were able to locate a bottle of the 2012. We decided to open it up with a delicious chicken tagine, and they seemed to enjoy each other's company much.

In relative terms, this wine seemed quite structured and focused, and at this stage in its life, very conservative. Mulberry shaded and slightly limpid in the glass, the nose started out really closed but over time revealed layers of dark berry fruit, spice, cedar box, and dried herbs. Taking a sip though, there was an almost savage dose of tannin, and a very mineral-driven profile. Full bodied, tart red and black fruit, and lots of persistence on the finish, which was savory (wood, herbs) and totally dry. Very puckering!

Honestly it held up well to the tagine, where a softer, plusher, or sweeter wine would have probably been lost on the palate. Maybe all of those sharp edges were a matter of youth; again, we felt the wine was closed and immature. 1-3 more years in a cellar would have probably helped it along greatly in our estimation, though maybe at that point it would have demanded a totally different pairing for food. Not bad at all, though we didn't find it memorable considering its asking price, at least at this stage in its development. Maybe a little patience would make this one pay off? It seems to have the stuffing for that.

Ben Carson is a religious fundamentalist. That makes him dangerous and unfit to be President. Fundamentalists, regardless of the religion, are the mortal enemies of individual freedom and self expression. They attempt to impose their centuries old, Medieval predjudices and bigoted values,on society.They deny the empirical truth of Global Warming and Evolution.They demonize the LGBT community. They try to interject their Sectarian Dogma into secular institutions, They replace the pursuit of tolerance, diversity, and openess, with demonization, dogma, and ignorance. Religion is dogma, not empirical and rational truth. Fundamentalists in the three major religions all show contempt for the "other", they subjugate women, deny Gays equal status.We can't have a President who harbors irrational fundamentalist superstitions and uses sectarian Dogma as a major component of their thought process.Fundamentalist is the euphemism for ignorance, sectarian tyranny, and bigotry.Carson and other right wing politicians inhabit an intellectual prison that makes them unqualified to be President

nothing I can tell, It's just that if you have enough words and letters you can find parts of those words that make up professions. But completely not needed to solve. And I didn't use any to solve. I think it would have slowed down to even look for them.

Just like AFTER you can find RIO and COPACABANA in the same puzzle. COMIC BOOK and BAT(man), (FLORA) ROSE and FAUNA, etc. Cute, but they wouldn't have helped solve the puzzle.

You are not obtuse.
I fail to be grateful for either of the Bush brothers.  Mo uses the superlative when she talks about them, are there 3?  I hope not.
Mike, are you aware that Prescott's business partner was Averill Harriman, later to become a NY Democrat Icon? Bush41 was no prize, so why expect his progeny to be Einsteins?

We cannot accept the assumption that Bush I can even be discussed as some kind of pharaoh who tragically spawned lesser progeny to manage his dynasty. The entire Bush family rose through oil companies, the CIA, and crooked backroom deals, starting with Prescott's embrace of the Nazis.

We should be grateful that "Poppy" only produced incoherent mediocrities. At least his legacy was not a collection of clever monsters, who could have run with family connections at Exxon and Saudi Arabia and done much more serious damage. And Jeb's, ineptness looks like gravitas on the stage compared to the competition.

The problem with T magazine is not simply one conflict of interest in one feature, but the fact that it exists at all. It panders to the very excesses of the superaffluent that are so corrosive to our society, as if to mock the reports and commentary on societal issues that the Times still manages to produce. I'm not advocating that the Times should look like Pravda, but the Times could wander away from serious or bad news without devoting a magazine exclusively to flaunting the hedonistic interests of a fraction of the top 1%.

I used to try to at least leaf through T, but now the magazine goes straight into my recycle bin because it became such a chore to find any journalism, let alone worth-while journalism, in between the masses of glossy ads. Just maybe I miss something once or twice a year that I may have liked, but it's worth it to avoid the nauseating promotion of people's lifestyles that are so removed from those of the rest of us that they are impossible to identify with.

Facebook, too, has a clause limiting users to California arbitration procedures... as those denied access to their accounts because FB has deemed their name "inauthentic" have discovered to their dismay.

Thus, users find their posts, personal messages, original writings and photography and graphics held "hostage" by a faceless bureaucracy which appears to treat the "authenticity" as a corporate whim, arbitrarily enforced.

No recourse...

Wow. That someone thinks human attempts to understand the will of God should be described as a "bitter civil war," on a "battlefield," -- is appalling. So much for "love one another as I have loved you."

Dr. K,

You might want to look at the total factors in trade prior to the Great Recession. In the US we have and are still trying to rearm the World and keep the consumables like explosives moving. I also think the rapidly growing telecommunications sector, cell phones et al, has rapidly changes and not necessarily in our favor. The same for processed agricultural products. The popular wisdom is China and other big trading partners are buying our bonds to finance the US government expenditures including our war faring. I received a report that China announced that it was extending its high speed rail network and would begin to export the rail systems that it will manufacture and I bet our States are dumb enough to buy them for the subsidized public transit systems.

http://nextbigfuture.com/2015/10/china-plans-to-triple-high-speed-rail.html

Of course this shakes me a little. The problem is it is a higher cost system in operations and maintenance and China would do better with the Powell and Danby 2nd generation system which only sips electrons. The US government needs to test, certify and compete the Powell and Danby system to fill the needs of this country in both interstate, and intra-urban transport for both freight trucks, passengers and automobiles with fares that are much lower than driving or carrying by truck on our crowded and dangerous highways.
used a baby kale/spinach/rabe mix and this was divine.

Publius, this article has a more complex sense of causation than you have understood.   The point is that gender stereotyping in the workplace is not vanishing but if anything reemerging, and that an uptick of gender stereotyping in children's merchandise may both reflect and extend that backlash.

What mediocre research informs this sloppy article.  But notice that the author tells us that "toys are more strictly gendered today than they were 50 years ago, when adult gender roles were much more separate."  What this suggests is that the relationship between roles and toys is not immediate, and may actually be thin to the point of vanishing.

My take on this as a parent is not so much that girls are discouraged from playing with so-called boys toys or doing so-called men's jobs, but that women are expected also to be attractive, as well as to be more than competent at running a home in addition to whatever their 'day job' is. In other words, additional requirements are imposed by our society upon women from early childhood onward, and that is patently unfair.
With all the obstruction Obama has from the right, especially about him being a divider, how can you expect him to get anywhere in Congress on getting school construction or roads built?
Good thinking Bob C. Let's make sure inner city kids are well armed.
You really think someone who refers to evolution as the work of Satan would respect separation of church and state? I've got a bridge for you...

I'm an atheist, an anti-theist, and I love evolution. I'm also a fiscal conservative and a Republican. A big problem for me is the fact that most Republican politicians are evolution deniers, and always it's for religious reasons. I still would rather vote for these people than vote for a liberal like Ms. Clinton. The only Republican candidate I'm interested in is Ben Carson. He would be the 2nd black president in a row and I think that's wonderful. Mr. Obama was not good for African Americans because he did nothing about the terrible schools black students often get stuck in. Obama was more interested in the supporting the teacher's union which has been part of the problem.

Ben Carson is way too religious but I believe he will respect our wall of separation between church and state. I also believe Carson will win both the nomination and the election.

Last but not least was the Domaine du Gour de Chaule, for which we located the 2010 vintage. Enjoyed it with stuffed porkchops and mushroom ravioli with cremini ragu.

This was (*is*...the last bit is getting swished around in my glass at the moment) a fantastic wine. It's a gorgeously deep ruby-garnet shade that catches light in a really pretty, flashy way. And it's got a really expressive aroma, loaded with kirsch liqueur and framboise, with notes of cedar, sandalwood, menthol, and fresh game. Very full bodied on the palate, with firm tannins and a ton of cherry/blackberry fruit. But it also has a lot of complexity that isn't fruit-driven. While lacking the minerality of the Pallieres, it does have noticeable herb and licorice flavors, and hints of baking cocoa emerge after a few hours. Moderately long, gripping finish. We love it.

The wine had a distinctly earthy, woody quality that went well with the mushroom side dish in particular. The bit of fat on the pork chop helped to compensate for the wine's drying tannins, and generally, nothing got in the way. Very nice pairing.

Overall, this was our favorite. Stylistically, it had a lot in common with the Cayron (though generally better to our taste in every way), and perfectly mature. But even the Pallieres seemed to fit in even if it had a harder edge. Lots of woodiness, lots of tart berry, and herbal notes. Like many of the other classes, "variations on a theme" seems to fit the bill. Thank you for another fun month!

Prescription drug pricing growth in the US is mostly fueled by specialty medications.  Sadly, the US lacks a robust pathway for approving generic equivalents for these large molecule drugs.  Were such a pathway to exist, the mechanisms that pharmacy benefits managers have in place (tight formularies that pit drug manufacturers of clinically equivalent alternatives against each other on price) would address the price inflation problem.

"We could have more respect for Carson if he were fighting to help other poor black children escape poverty, be well nourished and get a good education "
Perhaps the Carson Scholars Fund is an attempt to do something like that, but I'm inclined to doubt it. I suspect there might be a faith-based test involved. I have not folllowed the link nor done any research, so I emphasize that I am speculating. Now, if someone else has the energy find facts and tell me my speculation is wrong, I'll be happy for Dr. Carson, but still would be seriously worried if he became the next POTUS.
You call this news?
